segment.source: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk
segment.target: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk

segment.source: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk
segment.target: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk

segment.source: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk
segment.target: Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk

segment.source: This topic describes how to configure more than four disk partitions when you deploy Windows on BIOS and master boot record (MBR)-based devices.
segment.target: This topic describes how to configure more than four disk partitions when you deploy Windows on BIOS and master boot record (MBR)-based devices.

segment.source: Disk partition rules
segment.target: Disk partition rules

segment.source: On BIOS-based systems, you can designate one of the four standard partitions as an extended partition.
segment.target: On BIOS-based systems, you can designate one of the four standard partitions as an extended partition.

segment.source: An extended partition is a special partition that can be divided into additional partitions that are called logical partitions.
segment.target: An extended partition is a special partition that can be divided into additional partitions that are called logical partitions.

segment.source: An extended partition cannot store files.
segment.target: An extended partition cannot store files.

segment.source: An extended partition does not receive a partition ID.
segment.target: An extended partition does not receive a partition ID.

segment.source: You can include as many logical partitions as your disk can hold.
segment.target: You can include as many logical partitions as your disk can hold.

segment.source: Logical partitions can store files.
segment.target: Logical partitions can store files.

segment.source: You can use a logical partition as the Windows partition.
segment.target: You can use a logical partition as the Windows partition.

segment.source: For additional disk partition rules for BIOS-based systems, see Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions.
segment.target: For additional disk partition rules for BIOS-based systems, see Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions.

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Add system and utility partitions before you add the Windows partition.
segment.target: Add system and utility partitions before you add the Windows partition.

segment.source: Add the recovery tools partition immediately after the Windows partition.
segment.target: Add the recovery tools partition immediately after the Windows partition.

segment.source: When you use this partition order, then when future updates to the recovery tools are needed, the partition can be resized automatically.
segment.target: When you use this partition order, then when future updates to the recovery tools are needed, the partition can be resized automatically.

segment.source: Sample partition layout:
segment.target: Sample partition layout:

segment.source: Configuring disk partitions by using a DiskPart script in Windows PE
segment.target: Configuring disk partitions by using a DiskPart script in Windows PE

segment.source: For image-based deployment, boot the device by using Windows PE, and then use the DiskPart tool to create the partition structures on your destination devices.
segment.target: For image-based deployment, boot the device by using Windows PE, and then use the DiskPart tool to create the partition structures on your destination devices.

segment.source: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Windows PE reassigns disk letters alphabetically, beginning with the letter "C", without regard to the configuration in Windows Setup.
segment.target: Windows PE reassigns disk letters alphabetically, beginning with the letter "C", without regard to the configuration in Windows Setup.

segment.source: This configuration can change based on the presence of different drives, including USB flash drives.
segment.target: This configuration can change based on the presence of different drives, including USB flash drives.

segment.source: In these DiskPart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters "U", "V", "S", "W", and "R" to avoid drive-letter conflicts.
segment.target: In these DiskPart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters "U", "V", "S", "W", and "R" to avoid drive-letter conflicts.

segment.source: After the device reboots, Windows PE automatically assigns the letter "C" to the Windows partition.
segment.target: After the device reboots, Windows PE automatically assigns the letter "C" to the Windows partition.

segment.source: The Utility1, Utility2, system, and recovery image partitions do not receive drive letters.
segment.target: The Utility1, Utility2, system, and recovery image partitions do not receive drive letters.

segment.source: The following steps describe how to partition your hard drives and prepare to apply images.
segment.target: The following steps describe how to partition your hard drives and prepare to apply images.

segment.source: You can use the code in the sections that follow to complete these steps.
segment.target: You can use the code in the sections that follow to complete these steps.

segment.source: To partition hard drives and prepare to apply images
segment.target: To partition hard drives and prepare to apply images

segment.source: Save the code in the following sections as a text file (PrepareMyPartitions.txt) on a USB flash drive.
segment.target: Save the code in the following sections as a text file (PrepareMyPartitions.txt) on a USB flash drive.

segment.source: Use Windows PE to boot the destination device.
segment.target: Use Windows PE to boot the destination device.

segment.source: Use the command, where F: is the letter of the USB flash drive, to partition the drives.
segment.target: Use the command, where F: is the letter of the USB flash drive, to partition the drives.

segment.source: Sample code
segment.target: Sample code

segment.source: Next Steps
segment.target: Next Steps

segment.source: After you create the partitions, you can use a deployment script to apply the Windows images on the newly created partitions.
segment.target: After you create the partitions, you can use a deployment script to apply the Windows images on the newly created partitions.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
